stem: The nurse is preparing a combined dose of NPH and Regular insulin for a client. Based on the documentation in the High-Alert Med Verification Log, indicate whether each step in the preparation is correct or incorrect.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:30: Provider orders: Mix 20 units of NPH and 10 units of Regular insulin SC. 
07:45: Nurse has both vials and a sterile insulin syringe at the bedside. Second nurse is present for verification. 
08:00: Nurse performs the 'Clear before Cloudy' technique.

tabs.title: High-Alert Med Verification Log
tabs.content:
Action ItemNurse 1 ActionNurse 2 Verification
Vial InspectionRegular is Clear; NPH is CloudyConfirmed
Air Injection (NPH)Injects 20 units of airConfirmed
Air Injection (Req)Injects 10 units of airConfirmed
Withdrawal (Req)Pulls 10 units firstConfirmed
Withdrawal (NPH)Pulls 20 units secondConfirmed

tabs.title: Medication Safety Policy
tabs.content: Always withdraw the fast-acting (Regular) insulin into the syringe first to prevent contamination of the bottle with intermediate-acting (NPH) protein. Never shake NPH; always roll between palms.

rows.text: Shaking the NPH vial vigorously to mix the sediment
Injecting air into the NPH vial without touching the liquid
Drawing up the NPH (Cloudy) insulin before the Regular (Clear)
Drawing up the Regular (Clear) insulin before the NPH (Cloudy)
Verifying the total volume (30 units) with a second nurse

rationale.correct: Correct mixing (c1) requires injecting air into NPH (r2), then Regular, then withdrawing Regular first (r4) â€“ 'Clear before Cloudy'. A second nurse must verify high-alert meds (r5). Shaking is incorrect; always roll (r1). Drawing cloudy first is incorrect as it contaminates the clear vial (r3).
clinicalPearls: Wait! Clear before Cloudy! (Regular before NPH).
If you accidentally draw up too much NPH into a syringe that already has Regular, you MUST discard the whole syringe and start over.

questionTrap.trap: Believing air injection follows the same order as liquid withdrawal.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Air = NPH then Regular. Liquid = Regular then NPH. Just remember you ALWAYS want the Regular vial to stay pure!

mnemonic.title: Be an RN
mnemonic.expansion: R (Regular) comes before N (NPH) in life and in the syringe.
